history.content:
I have taken almost every class you mentioned so hopefully I can provide some good persepctive. 

70+54+140 is a lot. Like a lot a lot. Every course load is doable for some person, but I recommend against this schedule if you want to get the most out of each course. You can take this schedule and survive, but you will spend each week frantically trying to get all the assignments done, without being able to deep dive into conceptual understanding. 

These three courses are all problem set based, so if you like that, that's good, but most people find that hard to balance. 

I spent about 10-15 hours on each of the 70 and 140 hws , and about 3-4 hours on the Math54 hw (but I really took a shine to this course not everyone will feel the same way). 

The benefit of these three courses is that you don't reach the probability protion of 70 until the second half of the semester, so the stuff you learned in the the first half of 140 will make that path a bit easier. 

To the other courses:

Data100 is a nice course, and would balance 2 of those three nicely because of its more coding based assignments - a nice balance. I have not found Data100 to be much of a workload, but I came into the course with a lot of background knowledge that other people don't have, so they would probaby give a different time estimate. 

Stat133 is a very easy workload if you've taken 61ab already (for context - they don't cover functions till week 8 :/). However, if Stat133 is not required for the DS major, I am not sure if it would be worth your time. I didn't get a lot out of the course after 61abc (it was required for me as a Stats major). 

Side note:

Math 54 is a coreq for Data100, and I would double check if 54 is some kind of req for 140 (it wasn't in the pilot semester in which I took it, but I think that's changed). \

Lastly, 140 is an upper div math course, and some people would argue that it would be better to take it after taking more lower div math courses to build mathematical maturity (I know this word gets thrown around a lot but promise me it does exist). I took 140 as a freshman and did fine grade wise with only Math 1b under belt but I could have learned more with more math

Whether 70+54+140 is a good combination for you depends on your ability to handle things and your willingness to put in work

children.subject: How would you rank the order of difficulty/time commitment for those 3 courses? Do you still have time to do other things like exercising/clubs/eating?

For me personally, it's Stat 140 ~ CS 70 > Math 54. Maybe stat 140 is a bit harder than 70 for me, because I understand stats slowly :( The rank is the same regarding difficulty and time commitment (140 has weekly labs while 70 doesn't, but 70 has two midterms to prepare for). For me, it's actually 61b that's the most time-consuming due to the projects and less-organized course structure, so I'm having less extracurricular time. But I still watch movies, read novels and eat out, so I guess exercising and some clubs will be fine as well!

I'm taking the three courses, (CS 70, Math 54, and Stat 140) along with CS 61B this semester. Didn't have any knowledge of any course before, but I find the workload doable. Stat 140 prepares you very well for the second half of CS 70, so I actually feel relieved when 70 comes to the probability part. Math 54 is an okay class, as long as you understand the theorems. Still, if you're doing this schedule, I would suggest find a study group so that you won't be too stuck in the assignments. Thanks to my study group, I usually spend 5-6 hours on each of 70 and 140's homeworks. But definitely take a light-workload fourth class (not CS 61B sad:((

Also as a side note: if you have time in your schedule, I recommend doing the Student Learning Center's Adjunct course for Math 54 - it was so helpful to me! The instructor Brandon is amazing and he really helps you do concrete examples to understand the concepts and the required midterm and final review problems were almost more helpful than the practice tests for studying.

history.content: Hi all, I am a sophomore intending to major in Data Science and was wondering if this would be considered too big/much of a workload for me next semester. I wasn't able to get into Stat 89A and doubt I will get into Data 100, so I was just gonna take Math 54 to declare. However, I also want to take CS70 to prep for other CS UD courses I can use for the computational & inferential depth requirement (like CS 170). I was also considering taking Stat 133 but am not sure what combination would work best for me. I will have taken CS 61AB and Data 8.
history.subject: CS70 + Math 54 + Stat 140
